'ONCE MORE UNTO THE BREACH
, Today I begin my eleventh year of writing this column in your
campus newspaper.
I wasn't sure I'd be coming back this year. After a decade of
doing this column,I had retreated to my country seat, tired but
happy, to enjoy a nice long rest. But last night as I sat on my
verandah, peaceful and serene, humming the largo from A Long
Day's Night and worming my dog,a stranger suddenly appeared
before me.
He was a tall, clean-limbed man, crinkly-eyed and crookedgrinned, stalwart and virile. "How do you do," he said. "My
name is Stalwart Virile and I am with the Personna Stainless
fiteel Razor Blade people."
"Enchanted," I said."Take off your homburg and sit down."
I clapped my hands sharply."Norman!"I called."Another chair

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, FEBRUARY 12, 1965

Reston Sees 'Great Problems'
By MEL SHUSTER
James Reston, speaking at the
inauguration of the Frank R.
Kent lectures last Sunday, stated
that "there are great problems
and great questions ahead" in
the area of domestic affairs, and
that it is imperative for the
American people to understand
and discuss these problems if the
solutions being formulated are to
achieve success.
Addressing a capacity audience
at Shriver Hall, Reston appropriately dealt with a subject
to which the late Frank R. Kent
devoted much of his writing,
namely the fluctuation of the
public's reforming spirit and the
importance of keeping the public
aware of its political responsibilities.
Discussing recent American
Policy, Re s t on
Foreign
said, "We have, under
pressure, transformed our lives.
From an isolationist country, we
have taken on more responsibility than England or France at
the pinnacle of their power" and,
he feels, the United States has
admirably and successfully exercised its role of political and
economic leadership in the world.
The results of American internationalism on the domestic
scene have led Walter Lipman
to comment, "We are unsettled

to the very roots of our being
. . . We are not used to a complicated society." Consequently,
Reston feels that the time has
come to concentrate on internal
affairs, and that the efforts
of President Johnson towards
achieving his vision of the
"Great Society" must be supported and encouraged by the
American people.
Johnson's programs, Reston
emphasized, such as those treating poverty and education, will
be financed by the federal government but formed and ail:ministered by the local communities, thus requiring popular
understanding of the problems
being attacked. "We need,"
Reston said, "to involve the
nation in these questions, or our
politics, as Mr. Frank Kent has
pointed out, will increasingly become little more than a spectator sport."
To accomplish this objective is
partially the responsibility of the
universities and intellectuals in
American society, who, according to Reston, should have seized
Johnson's ideal, refined and expanded it, and who still must do
no if public involvement is to be
achieved.

Campus Notes
Student Council
The Honor Commission amendtrient.s on membership and its
files were approved by the Student Council in its meeting last
Monday night.
The amendment, which eliminates the engineering requirement, is designed to provide
greater flexibility in the membership of the Commission.
The amendment concerning the
files enables the Commission to
keep its record in an easier and
More orderly manner.
In other business, complaints
Were registered about the lack
of parking spare on campus and
the meager course offerenigs this
semester. Because of the lack
of courses, many of those offered
are over-crowded.
The undergraduates' position
In the new library was also a
subject for concern. Undergraduates are not allowed to use the
camels, but the tables do not
Provide enough room for the
students.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, FEBRUARY 12, 1965

YMCA
Gunther Schuller, one of
America's most versatile composers, and his orchestra will
present a concert Sunday. February 21, at 8.30 p.m. on the
Homewood campus.
Mr. Schuller has distinguished
himself both in the field of
formal compositions and the
freer realms of jazz. He is equally venturesome in a variety of
idioms of contemporary music
as he is in jazz. For his fusing
of jazz and contemporary classic
music he has coined the phrase
"third stream."
Tickets, on sale at the YMCA
range from $1.50-$2.50.

About Page 5
As reported in the News-teller last week, the Committee on Undergraduate Affairs has been considering
the questions of coeducation and of the size of the
undergraduate enrclIment. If such changes are decided
on, more dormitory space will he needed. Such a requirement would provide an excellent opportunity to
re-evaluate the present dormitory system at Hopkins.
Even if such changes do not come about, it can
be argued that the present dormitory system demands
a re-evaluation. It is in this spirit that we present the
study on page five.
We are not suggesting that the Hopkins dormitories
should be replaced immediately. Nor are we suggesting
that any one university's dormitory plan—however successful at that university—can he successfully applieti to
another university.
The study on page five hopes to raise questions.
Should dormitories merely house students or should
they also serve an academic function? Should dormitories he concerned with the social lives and emotional
well-being of the student?

Not Satisfied
Like the man who has eaten a hearty lunch but
looks forward to dinner; like the man who has eaten
steak for a week but looks forward to some chinese
food, we are happy, but not satisfied with the intellectually nutritious diet of politically and socially oriented
speakers brought to the campus.
We are glad to have heard Goldman, Reston, Johnson, and King. We don't want to miss Fulbright, Lodge,
Morse or Bundy. We appreciate anti are delighted that
the University is tieveloping and expanding as a great
tenter of political and social thought. We do feel, however, that some new themes are in demand; that other
areas of human interest should be explored in the
Shriver forum.
This is not to suggest that a dusty pedant's talk on
the u omen in Marlowe's plays might draw a crowd, but
that the University is obligated to provide some informal balance among those areas of interest which a
majority here have in common. Certainly everyone
wants to hear the President anti the Senate Foreign Relations chairman, but there are other safe areas, and
other giants of thought or accomplishment in these areas.
It should not be the responsibility of the Writing
Seminars to sponsor W. H. Auden, Archibald MacLeish,
John Steinbeck or Thornton Wilder; of the Art department to bring Ben Shahn or Salvador Dali; of the Philosophy department to bring Bertrand Russell or Martin
Buher; of the Film Guild to bring Alfred Hitchcock.
Norman Mailer, Erich Fromm, Helen Gurley Brown, and
many other potential speakers could shed some light,
however tinted, on the inside of man and complement
the fine visions of exterior reality with which we are
being well provided.
The prices of such speakers often exceeds the
resources of any Homewood agency except the University per se, but so does the ability to acquire the President of the United States and our foremost Senators and
Ambassadors exceed the powers of our historians and
political scientists. Statesmen speak here because their
subjects are of certain interest and concern to the potential audience. "Somebody up there" must remember
that the finer vision of life's fabric is built on the ability
to discriminate many kinds and colors of thread, and
that all the worlds around us are really seen by only
the inner eye. The next step is to give us credit for
interest in and concern for some non-material objects
of sight.

Honest Injun
When Eric Goldman spoke here, Dr. Eisenhower
thanked the crowd for coming inside on such a beautiful autumn day. When James Reston spoke in Shriver
Hall last Sunday, Dr. Eisenhower thanked the audience
for having come out in such a hard rain of niiserable
weather. When Senator Fulhright speaks here on a
typical March day, we suggest that the progression of
the Eisenhower charm will he best fulfilled if he thanks
those in attendance for having come out on such a typical
March day.

Anti-Kudos
Last year we complimented the Charles Street Review on its emergence from the dusty cocoon that was
its predecessor, Channels. For the first time in journalistic history, the News-Letter is taking back its
Kudos. We should have realized that a butterfly never
awes past the summer.

he newest and perhaps the most
bnpressive edifice for undergraduate
living at Harvard College is Leverett
House, seven stories of brick and glass
Which put the Crimson in the red to
the tune of $3 million.
Based on a new design called the
"elevator skip-stop plan," Leverett saves
space and cost by treating three floors
as a unit.
BY building split-level suites with the
living room in the middle floor and the
bedrooms above or below, the architects
Were able to eliminate costly corridors
two of the three floors.
This design is repeated on the second
Unit of three floors.
A typical suite in Leverett House consistst of a large (20'x15') living room on
One floor and four single bedrooms on
the floor either above or below the livbig room, plus two baths and a small
area for cooking.
Harvard supplies the students with a
bed, dresser, desk, two chairs and a refrigerator. The students typically spend
about $100 for living room furnishings,
hot plates, etc.
Douglass Roby, a senior from Chatham, New Jersey, felt that the biggest
asset of the suite idea was that "you
are able to escape from your roommates
when you want to and vice versa), and
the split-level design never becomes
claustrophobic or depressing, as is so
Often the case with the more stereotyped
dormitory rooms."
"Another good feature is that conflicts
With roommates are much less serious.
The soundproofing is good enough so
that one can sleep and another type if
It is necessary, or I can study while my
ioommates have a party in the living
room."
Each student's room is different in
design, either in its shape, placement or
Windows, or some other feature. This is
meant to preserve the individuality of
the students.
In addition to the 231 students in the
house there are about twenty faculty
members who live in the dorm and parin what is called "breakfast
table education". This is an informal

Ab

U

ndergraduate living at the Hopkins,
In the dorms, fraternities, and off-campus, reflects the Homewood academic
tradition of individual autonomy and
freedom.
Three years ago the university followed the approach of the vast majority
of campuses across the nation when it
decided to house freshmen and upperclassmen separately.
G. Wilson Schaffer, Dean of the
Homewood schools, commented on the
reasons for the change: "About four
years ago there seemed to be a serious
deterioration in dormitory living," he
said. "The freshmen appeared to have
more trouble adjusting."
"In addition, we found that while
many of the upperclassmen helped the
freshmen, others got them into bad
habits such as cutting class."
He also noted a broader change in
the emotional make-up of freshmen
since the war.
"The anxiety and interest, of parents
has changed vastly in the past twenty
years," he said. "Because the student
gets more support from his parents, he
is in some ways more dependent now
than in past years."
"What we are trying to do in the
freshman dorms, then, is to give the
students a little bit more on which they
can depend (housemasters) if they want
to, before letting them be completely
independent."
"In a sense," he said, "we are delaying
for a year. After that year, the students
are free to do what they want: continue
in the upperclass dormitories, live in a
fraternity, or live off-campus."
"In general our feeling is that the best
way for the student to grow up and adjust is to be on his own."
Perhaps the most important and constructive part of the dormitory organization is the housemaster system. The
work of the housemaster is defined not
so much by rules or restrictions as by

he dormitories at the University of
Pennsylvama' are oriented toward the
needs of the freshman student by providing an atmosphere that enables him
to adjust to college life.
At Pennsylvania, there is one large
dormitory complex that is built around
an upper and lower quadrangle; the
upper class dormitory residents live on
the upper quadrangle and the freshmen
on the lower quadrangle. Most of the
male dormitory residents are freshmen.
Most of the rooms in the dormitories
are doubles, but there are a few suites
and single rooms. The newer dormitories, built on the lower quadrangle,
have rooms that open on to long corridors, while the older dormitory rooms
face short hallways.
Living with the freshmen is a graduate counselor who is most instrumental
in the effort to effect the student's adjustment to college. The counselor assumes the role of an advisor and friend
of the students and has charge of about
fifteen freshmen. His importance was
stressed by Mr. Homer Wood, an assistant dean and head of the counselor
program, when he stated, "The freshmaw, year can be tough—the most average, normal student may hit a snag
which he could cope with if there was
someone around to help." But the
counselor is not a "professional counselor". The counselor is chosen for his
ability to make friends quickly and, his
maturity; he becomes, in a sense, an
"older friend" to the student, and helps
when he can by taking an interest in
the students' problems. The advice that
the counselor gives is dictaed by the
counselors own experience as an undergraduate and is not tempted by psychorogical training.
Though fraternities exist at Penn
they do not affect the freshman until
the second term. Most of the first term
freshman's social activity is confmed

complex have inadvertently become
study halls, but do provide a large area
for mingling after sports events. The
hours for permitting girls in the dormitories is the same for the freshmen as
it is for the upperclassmen.
During the second term about fifty
percent of the freshmen join one of the
thirty-six fraternities on campus. The
fraternity then becomes the center of
the students social activity. Students
are permitted to move into fraternity
houses the second year in lieu of remaining in the dorms and most fraternity men do so. Upperclassmen in the

ale College was forced to expand its
residence facilities when enrollment increased substantially following World
War I. Rather then merely build more
of the then current variety of dormitocry facilities, the administration decided to establish a residential college
system similar to those of Cambridge
and Oxford. Its small units were designed to be self-sufficient and helped
to maintain the atmosphere consonant
with a small academic community. The
term "college" merely applies to the
residential unit but has no actual academic significance.
Initially, eight colleges were constructed, each accommodating about
two-hundred and fifty students. In 1940
twomore colleges were added. Another
two colleges established after the Second
World War brought the total to twelve
residential colleges.
Each one of the colleges is selfsufficient, providing lodging, dining
facilities, recreation facilities, a library
and graduate counselors. Built about
quadrangles, the colleges provide a unit
that, according to an administration
pamphlet, "protects the student from
submersion in the vastness characteristic of most large institutions."
A faculty committee selects the students to be admitted to the residential
colleges; each college is comprised of
a cross-secion of the entire undergraduate community. Students from diverse
backgrounds, geographic
areas, and academic majors are housed
in one college, but the residences still
maintain their own esprit de corps.

Reston Sees 'Great Problems'
By MEL SHUSTER
James Reston, speaking at the
inauguration of the Frank R.
Kent lectures last Sunday, stated
that "there are great problems
and great questions ahead" in
the area of domestic affairs, and
that it is imperative for the
American people to understand
and discuss these problems if the
solutions being formulated are to
achieve success.
Addressing a capacity audience
at Shriver Hall, Reston appropriately dealt with a subject
to which the late Frank R. Kent
devoted much of his writing,
namely the fluctuation of the
public's reforming spirit and the
importance of keeping the public
aware of its political responsibilities.
Discussing recent American
Policy, Re s t on
Foreign
said, "We have, under
pressure, transformed our lives.
From an isolationist country, we
have taken on more responsibility than England or France at
the pinnacle of their power" and,
he feels, the United States has
admirably and successfully exercised its role of political and
economic leadership in the world.
The results of American internationalism on the domestic
scene have led Walter Lipman
to comment, "We are unsettled

to the very roots of our being
. . . We are not used to a complicated society." Consequently,
Reston feels that the time has
come to concentrate on internal
affairs, and that the efforts
of President Johnson towards
achieving his vision of the
"Great Society" must be supported and encouraged by the
American people.
Johnson's programs, Reston
emphasized, such as those treating poverty and education, will
be financed by the federal government but formed and ail:ministered by the local communities, thus requiring popular
understanding of the problems
being attacked. "We need,"
Reston said, "to involve the
nation in these questions, or our
politics, as Mr. Frank Kent has
pointed out, will increasingly become little more than a spectator sport."
To accomplish this objective is
partially the responsibility of the
universities and intellectuals in
American society, who, according to Reston, should have seized
Johnson's ideal, refined and expanded it, and who still must do
no if public involvement is to be
achieved.

"I will take up the burning issues that vex the American undergraduate!" I cried, bounding to my feet."I will explore, without fear or favor, such explosive questions as 'Are roommates
sanitary?' and 'Should proctors be given a saliva test?' and
Should capital punishment for pledges be abolished?'and 'Can
astudent of 19find happiness with an economics professor of80?";
"And will you also say a pleasant word from time to time about
'Personna Stainless Steel Razor Blades?" asked Mr. Virile.
"Sir," I said simply,"what other kind of word except pleasant
could I possibly say about Personna Blades, which give me more
luxury shavesthan Beep-Beep or any other blade I might name?':
"Another of my products is Burma Shave," said Mr. Virile.
:Tan you find it in your heart to mention Burma Shave occasionally?"
"But of course!" I declared. "For is not Burma Shave the
i'whisker-wiltingest lather in the land?'!
"Yes," he admitted.
And then he shook my hand again and smiled bravely and
was gone—a tall silhouette moving erectly into the setting sun.
llarewell, good tonsorialist!" I cried after him."Aloha!"
And turned with a will to my typewriter.

About Page 5
As reported in the News-teller last week, the Committee on Undergraduate Affairs has been considering
the questions of coeducation and of the size of the
undergraduate enrclIment. If such changes are decided
on, more dormitory space will he needed. Such a requirement would provide an excellent opportunity to
re-evaluate the present dormitory system at Hopkins.
Even if such changes do not come about, it can
be argued that the present dormitory system demands
a re-evaluation. It is in this spirit that we present the
study on page five.
We are not suggesting that the Hopkins dormitories
should be replaced immediately. Nor are we suggesting
that any one university's dormitory plan—however successful at that university—can he successfully applieti to
another university.
The study on page five hopes to raise questions.
Should dormitories merely house students or should
they also serve an academic function? Should dormitories he concerned with the social lives and emotional
well-being of the student?

Not Satisfied
Like the man who has eaten a hearty lunch but
looks forward to dinner; like the man who has eaten
steak for a week but looks forward to some chinese
food, we are happy, but not satisfied with the intellectually nutritious diet of politically and socially oriented
speakers brought to the campus.
We are glad to have heard Goldman, Reston, Johnson, and King. We don't want to miss Fulbright, Lodge,
Morse or Bundy. We appreciate anti are delighted that
the University is tieveloping and expanding as a great
tenter of political and social thought. We do feel, however, that some new themes are in demand; that other
areas of human interest should be explored in the
Shriver forum.
This is not to suggest that a dusty pedant's talk on
the u omen in Marlowe's plays might draw a crowd, but
that the University is obligated to provide some informal balance among those areas of interest which a
majority here have in common. Certainly everyone
wants to hear the President anti the Senate Foreign Relations chairman, but there are other safe areas, and
other giants of thought or accomplishment in these areas.
It should not be the responsibility of the Writing
Seminars to sponsor W. H. Auden, Archibald MacLeish,
John Steinbeck or Thornton Wilder; of the Art department to bring Ben Shahn or Salvador Dali; of the Philosophy department to bring Bertrand Russell or Martin
Buher; of the Film Guild to bring Alfred Hitchcock.
Norman Mailer, Erich Fromm, Helen Gurley Brown, and
many other potential speakers could shed some light,
however tinted, on the inside of man and complement
the fine visions of exterior reality with which we are
being well provided.
The prices of such speakers often exceeds the
resources of any Homewood agency except the University per se, but so does the ability to acquire the President of the United States and our foremost Senators and
Ambassadors exceed the powers of our historians and
political scientists. Statesmen speak here because their
subjects are of certain interest and concern to the potential audience. "Somebody up there" must remember
that the finer vision of life's fabric is built on the ability
to discriminate many kinds and colors of thread, and
that all the worlds around us are really seen by only
the inner eye. The next step is to give us credit for
interest in and concern for some non-material objects
of sight.

Honest Injun
When Eric Goldman spoke here, Dr. Eisenhower
thanked the crowd for coming inside on such a beautiful autumn day. When James Reston spoke in Shriver
Hall last Sunday, Dr. Eisenhower thanked the audience
for having come out in such a hard rain of niiserable
weather. When Senator Fulhright speaks here on a
typical March day, we suggest that the progression of
the Eisenhower charm will he best fulfilled if he thanks
those in attendance for having come out on such a typical
March day.

Anti-Kudos
Last year we complimented the Charles Street Review on its emergence from the dusty cocoon that was
its predecessor, Channels. For the first time in journalistic history, the News-Letter is taking back its
Kudos. We should have realized that a butterfly never
awes past the summer.

he newest and perhaps the most

Based on a new design called the

space and cost by treating three floors
as a unit.
BY building split-level suites with the

bedrooms above or below, the architects
Were able to eliminate costly corridors
two of the three floors.

Unit of three floors.
A typical suite in Leverett House consistst of a large (20'x15') living room on
One floor and four single bedrooms on
the floor either above or below the livbig room, plus two baths and a small
area for cooking.
Harvard supplies the students with a
bed, dresser, desk, two chairs and a refrigerator. The students typically spend
about $100 for living room furnishings,
hot plates, etc.

asset of the suite idea was that "you
are able to escape from your roommates
when you want to and vice versa), and
the split-level design never becomes
claustrophobic or depressing, as is so
Often the case with the more stereotyped
dormitory rooms."
"Another good feature is that conflicts
With roommates are much less serious.
The soundproofing is good enough so
that one can sleep and another type if
It is necessary, or I can study while my
ioommates have a party in the living
room."
Each student's room is different in
design, either in its shape, placement or
Windows, or some other feature. This is
meant to preserve the individuality of
the students.
In addition to the 231 students in the
house there are about twenty faculty
members who live in the dorm and parin what is called "breakfast
table education". This is an informal

ndergraduate living at the Hopkins,
In the dorms, fraternities, and off-campus, reflects the Homewood academic
tradition of individual autonomy and
freedom.
Three years ago the university followed the approach of the vast majority
of campuses across the nation when it
decided to house freshmen and upperclassmen separately.
G. Wilson Schaffer, Dean of the
Homewood schools, commented on the
reasons for the change: "About four
years ago there seemed to be a serious
deterioration in dormitory living," he
said. "The freshmen appeared to have
more trouble adjusting."
"In addition, we found that while
many of the upperclassmen helped the
freshmen, others got them into bad
habits such as cutting class."
He also noted a broader change in
the emotional make-up of freshmen
since the war.
"The anxiety and interest, of parents
has changed vastly in the past twenty
years," he said. "Because the student
gets more support from his parents, he
is in some ways more dependent now
than in past years."
"What we are trying to do in the
freshman dorms, then, is to give the
students a little bit more on which they
can depend (housemasters) if they want
to, before letting them be completely
independent."
"In a sense," he said, "we are delaying
for a year. After that year, the students
are free to do what they want: continue
in the upperclass dormitories, live in a
fraternity, or live off-campus."
"In general our feeling is that the best
way for the student to grow up and adjust is to be on his own."
Perhaps the most important and constructive part of the dormitory organization is the housemaster system. The
work of the housemaster is defined not
so much by rules or restrictions as by

he dormitories at the University of

Most of the rooms in the dormitories

have rooms that open on to long corridors, while the older dormitory rooms
face short hallways.
Living with the freshmen is a graduate counselor who is most instrumental
in the effort to effect the student's adjustment to college. The counselor assumes the role of an advisor and friend
of the students and has charge of about
fifteen freshmen. His importance was
stressed by Mr. Homer Wood, an assistant dean and head of the counselor
program, when he stated, "The freshmaw, year can be tough—the most average, normal student may hit a snag

counselor is not a "professional counselor". The counselor is chosen for his
ability to make friends quickly and, his
maturity; he becomes, in a sense, an
"older friend" to the student, and helps
when he can by taking an interest in
the students' problems. The advice that
the counselor gives is dictaed by the
